description: Complain about or report company for breaking the law or committing fraud, running scams, or selling faulty products of services

details.body:
Find out how to complain about a company that:

  • is committing fraud or running scams
  • sold you a faulty product or service
  • owes you money
  • files late or fraudulent documents
  • is evading tax
  • is causing harm to its suppliers or customers

The process is different if you want to:

  • report a disqualified director
  • report a company using your personal details without your permission
  • complain about the re-use of a company name

nodes.body: Check the Companies House register if you do not know the status of the company.

options.label: Yes, the company is still active
No, the company is being liquidated (being 'wound up')
No, the  company has been dissolved

nodes.title: Is the company active?

options.label: Financial harm to customers or suppliers
Fraud or a scam (for example a fake investment scheme, a ‘Ponzi’ or pyramid scheme)
Serious and complex fraud (this usually involves hundreds of millions of pounds and damages the economy)

nodes.title: Are you complaining about a financial service?

nodes.body:
Complain to Companies House if a company has not filed its annual accounts or confirmation statements (previously annual returns), or has filed fraudulent documents.

To make a complaint, email enquiries@companieshouse.gov.uk.
nodes.title: Complain to Companies House

nodes.body:
Use Citizens Advice to find out what to do if you’ve:

  • been sold faulty or counterfeit goods
  • received poor service
  • had problems with contracts
  • had problems with builders

You can also get advice on your consumer rights, for example when you’re entitled to a refund.

If you cannot resolve a complaint, an ‘ombudsman’ can investigate complaints about organisations for free.

Use the Ombudsman Association website to find the right ombudsman for your complaint.
nodes.title: Contact Citizens Advice or an ombudsman

nodes.body:
You might be able to:

  • make a court claim - sometimes knows as ‘small claims court’
  • send a statutory demand

Find out other options if a company owes you money.
nodes.title: A company owes you money

nodes.body: Report serious and complex fraud, bribery and corruption to the Serious Fraud Office.
nodes.title: Complain to the Serious Fraud Office

nodes.body:
The Insolvency Service can investigate companies committing fraud and scams. 

They cannot investigate all complaints. Your complaint is more likely to be investigated if the fraud or scam:

  • is recent or ongoing
  • involves a lot of money
  • affects a lot of people
  • targets vulnerable people

If they find enough evidence, they can:

  • apply to court to have the company closed down
  • disqualify the company’s directors
  • carry out a criminal investigation to find out if the company has committed an offence

They cannot help you resolve a dispute or help you get your money back. Find out your options if a company owes you money.

After you complain

Once the Insolvency Service has reviewed your complaint they can:

  • decide not to take further action 
  • pass your complaint on to another public body
  • decide to carry out a confidential investigation

The Insolvency Service will not contact you or give you any details if they decide to investigate.

Contact the Insolvency Service

You can either:

  • complain to the Insolvency Service online  
  • write to the Insolvency Service

Compliance and Targeting
Investigations and Enforcement Services
Insolvency Service
3rd Floor Cannon House
18 Priory Queensway
Birmingham
B4 6FD

You can get a copy of the complaint form sent to an email address by calling the Insolvency Service answerphone.

Insolvency Service
Telephone: 0303 003 1744
24-hour answerphone
Find out about call charges

Other ways to report fraud

You can also report a fraud or scam to Action fraud.
nodes.title: Tell the Insolvency Service

nodes.body: Follow the company’s complaints procedure. You can usually then complain to the Financial Ombudsman Service if you’re unhappy with their response.
nodes.title: Complain to the Financial Ombudsman Service

nodes.body:
Report someone to HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) if you think they’re evading tax, for example by:

  • not telling HMRC about what they owe
  • keeping business ‘off the books’ by dealing in cash and not giving receipts
  • hiding money, shares or other assets in an offshore bank account (‘offshore tax evasion’)
nodes.title: Report tax evasion to HMRC

nodes.body:
Contact the official receiver or insolvency practitioner if the company you want to complain about:

  • has gone into administration
  • has gone into receivership

Check the Companies House register if you do not know the official receiver or insolvency practitioner responsible for the case.
nodes.title: Complain to the Insolvency Practitioner or Official Receiver

nodes.body:
You can apply to have a company restored and complain to the Insolvency Service, so they can consider whether to investigate the dissolved company.

What you should do depends on your situation.

Apply to have a company restored

You can apply to have a company restored if:

  • they owe you money
  • you did business with them
  • you worked for them
  • you’re responsible for their employee pension fund
  • you have a shared or competing interest in land
  • you were a shareholder or director when it was dissolved

Complain to the Insolvency Service

You can complain to the Insolvency Service about a dissolved company if:

  • the company owes you money from doing something illegal or wrong, for example a scam or fraud
  • there are claims that the company has done something illegal or wrong, even if they do not owe you money

You can either:

  • complain to the Insolvency Service online
  • call or write to the Insolvency Service

Insolvency Service
Telephone: 0303 003 1744
24-hour answerphone
Find out about call charges

Compliance and Targeting
Investigations and Enforcement Services
Insolvency Service
3rd Floor Cannon House
18 Priory Queensway
Birmingham
B4 6FD

What happens next

If the Insolvency Service decides that your complaint is serious enough, they will either:

  • carry out an investigation
  • pass your complaint on to another public body if it relates to the actions of individuals or of other companies

If they find anything wrong and have enough evidence, they may also carry out a criminal investigation if the company has committed an offence.
nodes.title: A company has been dissolved

nodes.body:
You can either:

  • complain to the Insolvency Service online
  • call or write to the Insolvency Service

Insolvency Service
Telephone: 0303 003 1744
24-hour answerphone
Find out about call charges

Compliance and Targeting
Investigations and Enforcement Services
Insolvency Service
3rd Floor Cannon House
18 Priory Queensway
Birmingham
B4 6FD

What happens next

If the Insolvency Service decides that your complaint is serious enough, they will either:

  • carry out a confidential investigation
  • pass your complaint on to another public body

If they find anything wrong and have enough evidence, they might ask a court to:

  • close the company down
  • disqualify the company’s directors

They may also carry out a criminal investigation if they find the company has committed an offence.
nodes.title: Complain to the Insolvency Service
